person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

person_639.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
person_639.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

person_387.name: John JoachimBecher
person_387.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_422.name: HennigBrand
person_422.description: German alchemist who accidentally discovered phosphorus.

person_423.name: Johann vonLöwenstern-Kunckel
person_423.description: German/Swedish chemist and apothecary. Later director of the laboratory and glass works of Brandenburg.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_425.name: AmbroseGodfrey-Hanckwitz
person_425.description: German-born British apothecary who worked as Boyle's assistant and later became a phosphorus manufacturer. FRSL.

person_426.name: JeanHellot
person_426.description: French chemist and journalist who contributed to early studies on phosphorus and worked on applied aspects in dyeing, metallurgy, mining, and porcelain manufacture. ForMemRSL.

person_393.name: Charles Francois de Cisternay duFay
person_393.description: French chemist and superintedent of the Jardin du Roi, who worked on electricity. ForMemRSL.

person_427.name: Étienne FrançoisGeoffroy
person_427.description: French physician and chemist, best known for his 1718 affinity tables. ForMemRSL.

person_022.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
person_022.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

person_739.name: Johan GottliebGahn
person_739.description: Swedish chemist and metallurgist who isolated manganese in 1774.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_169.name: Mount Vesuvius
place_169.description: Mount Vesuvius is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy.

place_655.name: Parys Mine
place_655.description: A mountain in Northern Wales known for copper-mining.

place_461.name: Anglesey
place_461.description: Anglesey is an island, and county, on the north-west coast of Wales.

place_849.name: Lake Solfatara
place_849.description: The lake is in the Campagna of Rome, Italy, near Tivoli.

place_570.name: Hamburg
place_570.description: Hamburg is one of Germany's three city-states alongside Berlin and Bremen, and is surrounded by Schleswig-Holstein to the north and Lower Saxony to the south.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_571.name: Mull
place_571.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.
